Product description

The PS5 console unleashes new gaming possibilities that you never anticipated. Experience lightning fast loading with an ultra-high speed SSD, deeper immersion with support for haptic feedback, adaptive triggers, and 3D Audio*, and an all-new generation of incredible PlayStation games. Lightning Speed - Harness the power of a custom CPU, GPU, and SSD with Integrated I/O that rewrite the rules of what a PlayStation console can do. Stunning Games - Marvel at incredible graphics and experience new PS5 features. Play a back catalog of supported PS4 games. Breathtaking Immersion - Discover a deeper gaming experience with support for haptic feedback, adaptive triggers, and 3D Audio technology. Vertical stand sold separately. *3D audio via built-in TV speakers or analog/USB stereo headphones. Set up and latest system software update required.

How are ratings calculated?
To calculate the overall star rating and percentage breakdown by star, we don’t use a simple average. Instead, our system considers things like how recent a review is and if the reviewer bought the item on Amazon. It also analyzes reviews to verify trustworthiness.

Amazon Customer
4 out of 5 stars
How "pro" is the PS5 Pro?
How "pro" is the PS5 Pro? Well, that's a loaded question. Some elements make it stand out for sure, the extra graphical horsepower, 2TB SSD, game boost for existing PS5 titles, sharpened PS4 titles, extra Ray Tracing features, PSSR etc On the other hand it sells for just over 1k CAD with tax, and it ships with just the updated console and a base controller which comes packed in what is perhaps the cheapest consumer electronics packaging I've ever seen at this price point. It all seems a bit skimpy and I do think they should have at least included the vertical stand... or disc drive, perhaps a DualSense Edge controller to balance things out a bit and make it FEEL "professional" out of the box... hell, even a digital code for AstroBot would have been fine, but this is Sony, and that's simply not how they operate.So in reality, this is an upgrade for enthusiasts. Enthusiasts with a TV capable of taking advantage of the upgrades to the base PS5. If you bought the PS4 Pro back in 2016, or the Xbox One X a year later, this is console might be for you. If you have a large digital library this would also come in handy as currently many of the games on the "Pro Enhanced" list are older first part titles like Horizon, Spider-Man and The Last Of Us 1&2. If you're into future proofing and you have a 4k TV capable of 120Hz and VRR, you may also want to consider grabbing this version of the console, especially if this is a first time PS5 purchase.I have tested this with a bunch of titles on a 4k TV with all the bells and whistles and this console does do some really neat things. It makes games, like Horizon or Spider-Man, which always looked good, look even better and run smoother. It also makes games like FF7 rebirth, which was a bit shaky out of the gate, perform and look much better, also Stellar Blade has never looked this good. I also tried some PS4 titles to check out how it "enhanced" those, and I must say whatever they're doing made Red Dead Redemption 2 look even better than it already did... especially the interface.So, here's how I look at this. The base PS5 ships with 1TB of space. If you think about the price of SSD's it costs $110-150 for a brand name 1TB SSD to add into a base PS5. The PS5 Pro ships with 2TB... The PS5 pro is $300 more than the base PS5... if you consider the extra SSD size, and the performance boosts, I honestly don't think the extra $300 is unreasonable, though again, they probably should have at least included the stand. Do I think this console is overpriced? Yes. It's the most expensive console to ever hit the market, but it's also the closest to a gaming PC running a decent modern video card... and that video card on it's own might be a little cheaper, but comparable in price to this entire PS5 Pro.In the end you have to decide if you have the money to toss at this thing, and if you have the TV capable of taking advantage of the PS5 Pro's capabilities. If you're on an older 1080p TV or 4k panel which can't hit 120hz and/or lacks VRR, you may want to hold off. I like what I see so far, and I look forward to seeing what developers do to take advantage of the Pro features... for now, I'm giving this a 4/5 for the bare bones release and the overall price/high barrier of entry.

    4.0 out of 5 stars How "pro" is the PS5 Pro?
    Reviewed in Canada on November 9, 2024
    Style: PS5 ProColour Name: Playstation 5 Pro ConsoleVerified Purchase
    How "pro" is the PS5 Pro? Well, that's a loaded question. Some elements make it stand out for sure, the extra graphical horsepower, 2TB SSD, game boost for existing PS5 titles, sharpened PS4 titles, extra Ray Tracing features, PSSR etc On the other hand it sells for just over 1k CAD with tax, and it ships with just the updated console and a base controller which comes packed in what is perhaps the cheapest consumer electronics packaging I've ever seen at this price point. It all seems a bit skimpy and I do think they should have at least included the vertical stand... or disc drive, perhaps a DualSense Edge controller to balance things out a bit and make it FEEL "professional" out of the box... hell, even a digital code for AstroBot would have been fine, but this is Sony, and that's simply not how they operate.

    So in reality, this is an upgrade for enthusiasts. Enthusiasts with a TV capable of taking advantage of the upgrades to the base PS5. If you bought the PS4 Pro back in 2016, or the Xbox One X a year later, this is console might be for you. If you have a large digital library this would also come in handy as currently many of the games on the "Pro Enhanced" list are older first part titles like Horizon, Spider-Man and The Last Of Us 1&2. If you're into future proofing and you have a 4k TV capable of 120Hz and VRR, you may also want to consider grabbing this version of the console, especially if this is a first time PS5 purchase.

    I have tested this with a bunch of titles on a 4k TV with all the bells and whistles and this console does do some really neat things. It makes games, like Horizon or Spider-Man, which always looked good, look even better and run smoother. It also makes games like FF7 rebirth, which was a bit shaky out of the gate, perform and look much better, also Stellar Blade has never looked this good. I also tried some PS4 titles to check out how it "enhanced" those, and I must say whatever they're doing made Red Dead Redemption 2 look even better than it already did... especially the interface.

    So, here's how I look at this. The base PS5 ships with 1TB of space. If you think about the price of SSD's it costs $110-150 for a brand name 1TB SSD to add into a base PS5. The PS5 Pro ships with 2TB... The PS5 pro is $300 more than the base PS5... if you consider the extra SSD size, and the performance boosts, I honestly don't think the extra $300 is unreasonable, though again, they probably should have at least included the stand. Do I think this console is overpriced? Yes. It's the most expensive console to ever hit the market, but it's also the closest to a gaming PC running a decent modern video card... and that video card on it's own might be a little cheaper, but comparable in price to this entire PS5 Pro.

    In the end you have to decide if you have the money to toss at this thing, and if you have the TV capable of taking advantage of the PS5 Pro's capabilities. If you're on an older 1080p TV or 4k panel which can't hit 120hz and/or lacks VRR, you may want to hold off.     Hal9001
    4.0 out of 5 stars How "pro" is the PS5 Pro?
    Reviewed in Canada on November 9, 2024
    How "pro" is the PS5 Pro? Well, that's a loaded question. Some elements make it stand out for sure, the extra graphical horsepower, 2TB SSD, game boost for existing PS5 titles, sharpened PS4 titles, extra Ray Tracing features, PSSR etc On the other hand it sells for just over 1k CAD with tax, and it ships with just the updated console and a base controller which comes packed in what is perhaps the cheapest consumer electronics packaging I've ever seen at this price point. It all seems a bit skimpy and I do think they should have at least included the vertical stand... or disc drive, perhaps a DualSense Edge controller to balance things out a bit and make it FEEL "professional" out of the box... hell, even a digital code for AstroBot would have been fine, but this is Sony, and that's simply not how they operate.

    So in reality, this is an upgrade for enthusiasts. Enthusiasts with a TV capable of taking advantage of the upgrades to the base PS5. If you bought the PS4 Pro back in 2016, or the Xbox One X a year later, this is console might be for you. If you have a large digital library this would also come in handy as currently many of the games on the "Pro Enhanced" list are older first part titles like Horizon, Spider-Man and The Last Of Us 1&2. If you're into future proofing and you have a 4k TV capable of 120Hz and VRR, you may also want to consider grabbing this version of the console, especially if this is a first time PS5 purchase.

    I have tested this with a bunch of titles on a 4k TV with all the bells and whistles and this console does do some really neat things. It makes games, like Horizon or Spider-Man, which always looked good, look even better and run smoother. It also makes games like FF7 rebirth, which was a bit shaky out of the gate, perform and look much better, also Stellar Blade has never looked this good. I also tried some PS4 titles to check out how it "enhanced" those, and I must say whatever they're doing made Red Dead Redemption 2 look even better than it already did... especially the interface.

    So, here's how I look at this. The base PS5 ships with 1TB of space. If you think about the price of SSD's it costs $110-150 for a brand name 1TB SSD to add into a base PS5. The PS5 Pro ships with 2TB... The PS5 pro is $300 more than the base PS5... if you consider the extra SSD size, and the performance boosts, I honestly don't think the extra $300 is unreasonable, though again, they probably should have at least included the stand. Do I think this console is overpriced? Yes. It's the most expensive console to ever hit the market, but it's also the closest to a gaming PC running a decent modern video card... and that video card on it's own might be a little cheaper, but comparable in price to this entire PS5 Pro.

    In the end you have to decide if you have the money to toss at this thing, and if you have the TV capable of taking advantage of the PS5 Pro's capabilities. If you're on an older 1080p TV or 4k panel which can't hit 120hz and/or lacks VRR, you may want to hold off. I like what I see so far, and I look forward to seeing what developers do to take advantage of the Pro features... for now, I'm giving this a 4/5 for the bare bones release and the overall price/high barrier of entry.
